metadata.title: Plica Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Anteromedial aspect of the knee; fold of synovial membrane. Several plicae can be found in the knee: 1) superior, 2) medial, 3) lateral, and 4) inferior plica. The most clinically relevant and most commonly involved structure is the medial plica, which is found under the medial retinaculum and vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) runs parallel to the medial patella, and inserts distally onto the infrapatellar fat pad(5)
description: Inflammation or fibrotic thickening of plica (synovial fold) in the knee. It is thought to be a remnant of embryologic development. This medial patellar membrane can cause pain, catching, and inflammation(4)

ICD-10 codes.M65.86: other synovitis and tenosynovitis, lower extremity
ICD-10 codes.M67.50: plica syndrome, unspecified knee (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients typically present with an intermittent dull ache just medial to the patella but above the joint line, as well as pain and tenderness under the patella. Other complaints may be catching, clicking, giving way, locking, snapping, and tightness. Symptoms may begin insidiously with a history of overuse or suddenly from direct/blunt trauma. On occasion, symptoms may appear bilaterally(4)

Physical activities involving repetitive knee flexion and extension (e.g., stair-climbing, squatting, rowing, cycling) can aggravate the condition. Sustained knee flexion postures, such as during prolonged sitting, can also increase symptoms when inflammation is present(4)

A fibrotic cord over the medial femoral condyle may be palpable, coupled with an audible sound during ROM. Pain with palpation of the cord over the anteromedial knee is the most characteristic sign of plica syndrome
This syndrome is found most frequently in teenagers, when meniscal and ligamentous injuries are still rare Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Although plicae are common, pathological plicae are rare. Thus, the diagnosis of plica syndrome should come after exclusion of other, more common anteromedial knee conditions (e.g., meniscal tears, ligament injuries, chondromalacia)
Pathological plicae can also be concomitant with other intraarticular knee conditions(5)

causes: Direct blow or trauma to knee tissue(5)
Repetitive knee flexion and extension activities
Secondary dysfunction of knee internal derangement, such as a meniscus tear or osteochondritis dissecans
pathogenesis: It is widely believed that plicae arise from mesenchyme (embryonic connective tissue) during embryologic developmentof the knee at 3–4 months of fetal life.(4)The mesenchyme forms the membranes that eventually divide the differentcompartments of the knee. Plicae are composed of excess tissue from these membranes that failed to be reabsorbed andeventually become inward folds of the synovial lining(4,5)

Plicae commonly are asymptomatic and have been reported to be present in 50% of the population. Unfortunately, theirpresence can also lead to an inflammatory state or hypertrophic fibrosis if trauma or repetitive activity is introduced,respectively

Repetitive plica inflammation probably leads to the hypertrophic fibrosis, with proliferation of nerves and blood vessels.This progression results in an enlarged medial plica that is less elastic and can either become impinged between the medialfemoral condyle and the medial facet of the patella during knee flexion or create a shearing force over the medial femoralcondyle(5)

Close proximity of the plica under the VMO muscle may cause pain and associated patellar tracking disorders. Fibroticchanges of the plica can lead to degeneration and softening of the patellofemoral joint cartilage(5)
The progression has even been postulated to be a cause for medial compartment degeneration, or knee osteoarthritis, asarticular cartilage is sloughed off by the medial plica(5)
risk factors: Plica syndrome is equally common in men and women, who typically are young and active
The condition is most common in the 20’s and 30’s, but it is also found on occasion in children or teenagers
Participation in physical activity not typical of one’s normal activities (e.g., “weekend warriors”) or not appropriate forone’s current fitness level
Vigorous recreational activity (e.g., running, cycling, swimming, horseback riding, gymnastics) during adolescence
Recent change in running surface, footwear, or orthotics

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Have pain and function gradually worsened, or did pain start suddenly? Was onset of pain related to trauma or overuse? What activities are associated with symptoms (e.g., use of stairs, squatting, prolonged sitting, sports)? Any episodes of joint clicking or locking?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management for knee pain. Has patient modified activity level and/or used a knee brace? How has the pain responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs often are recommended
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  The diagnosis usually is made clinically(3)
Radiographs may be useful if another condition is suspected, but unfortunately they do not detect plicae
MRI is usually not recommended unless other knee pathology is suspected. However, MRI has been reported to be helpful for evaluating the thickness and extension of the medial plicae(5)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Physical activities involving repetitive knee flexion and extension (e.g., stair-climbing,  squatting, rowing, cycling, sit to stand) may be reported to be aggravating(4,5) -Sustained knee flexion postures, such as during prolonged sitting, may also increase symptoms as the plica is pulled taut(5) -Popping, clicking, catching when moving the knee from 90 degrees of flexion to extension. Instability and feeling of knee “giving way” have also been reported(5) -Knee pain is eased when knee is static at 0 degrees extension, such as in standing(5)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patients typically complain of localized ache and tenderness medial to patella but above the joint line
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients typically report an intermittent dull ache with a feeling of catching, clicking, giving way, locking, snapping, or tightness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Symptoms such as weight loss, pallor, fever, and anorexia are rare systemic symptoms, more commonly seen in osteosarcoma Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any previous skeletal problems or injury to the affected joint?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Inquire about recreational activity, sports, and occupation
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document use of any assistive or adaptive devices
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height and weight. Quadriceps atrophy may be assessed by taking muscle girth measurements
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need for, proper fit, and use of knee brace and/or other ambulatory assistive device
relevant tests and measures.balance: Test reaction to displacement of center of gravity in standing position and balance in 1-leg  stand. Can be normal if the knee is straight and pain/swelling is not extensive
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: If patient is an athlete, assess sports-related motion related to pain
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for antalgic gait or excessive compensatory mechanismsEvaluate knee joint and patellofemoral joint mobility and stability. Medial gliding of the patella may induce a characteristic popping sound or pain at 30 degrees flexion. Include knee ligament stress tests and meniscal tests
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of the lower extremity, especially for the hip abductor and external rotator musculature if gait deficits are observed. Check quadriceps strength in chronic cases or where atrophy is visible
observation inspection palpation includi: Quadriceps atrophy is common in chronic cases(5)
Tenderness medial to the patella over the medial femoral condyle will most likely be found with a pathological medial plica(4)
Crepitus may be palpable during knee motion
A painful arc may be experienced between 30˚ and 60˚ during knee motion,although popping may be felt under the examiner’s fingers between 45˚ and 60˚ flexion(5)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Look for abnormal joint alignment, such as genu varus or excessive tibial torsion. Compare lower extremities for asymmetry in standing at the pelvis, hip, knee, and foot
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for loss of ROM due to pain, joint locking, or muscle shortening/stiffness. Quadriceps tightness is often seen in patients with a symptomatic plica(5)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Should be normalUsually not impaired, except in severe cases
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosiswith the knee held in 30 degrees of flexion, the examiner pushes the patella medially. Pain is reproduced as the plica is pinched between the femur and the patella(5)Questionnaire given to a patient to assess for items such as gait, ability to use assistive devices, pain, swelling, squatting, and climbing stairs

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Electrotherapy  contraindications (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(1)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Activity-related  knee pain. Guided intervention needed for activity modification and pain management Rule out  (4,5) Hoffa syndrome Patellofemoral pain syndrome Meniscus injury Chondromalacia Pes anserine bursitis Medial collateral ligament injury Patella bipartite Hip pathology if an adolescent Degenerative joint disease Osteochondritis dissecans Osteosarcoma
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedic surgeon if conservative treatment fails Orthotist for custom orthotics
treatment summary: There is general agreement that the initial management of medial synovial plica syndrome should be conservative. Conservative treatment has been reported to be effective in 60% of cases. The goals of conservative treatment are joint protection, pain management, and restoration of function. Attempt to medialize the patella with interventions such as vastus medialis obliquus strengthening, taping, or bracing. Orthopedic referral is indicated when symptoms persist beyond this time frame(6) . minimize swelling: Lysholm score, stroke test for knee joint effusion measurement(2)
increase maintain sufficient strength: Manual muscle testing, Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS), Lysholm score
age-appropriate proprioception and bala: Balance and proprioception tests, Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS), Lysholm score

maintenance or prevention: Ongoing joint protection during potentially aggravating activities
Maintain lower extremity strength and flexibility
